qas.question: Who was a notable critic of Hegel?
For whom did Kierkegaard argue reality cannot be a system?
According to Kierkegaard, why can't reality be a system for human beings?
Even though Kierkegaard does not believe in the possibility of an existential system of reality, what sort of system can exist?
What does Kierkegaard blur the lines between?
Why did Kierkegaard believe humans could have a system for reality?
Kierkegaard said a logical system and what other system was possible?
What did Kierkegaard say could explain all of reality?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Kierkegaard<b4_0/><a0_0/> criticised Hegel's idealist philosophy in several of his works, particularly his claim to <b8_0>a comprehensive system<b8_0/> that could explain the whole of reality. Where Hegel argues that an ultimate understanding of the logical structure of the world is an understanding of the logical structure of God's mind, Kierkegaard asserting that for God reality can be a system but it cannot be so for any <a1_0>human<a1_0/> individual because <b6_0>both reality and <a2_0>humans<b6_0/> are incomplete<a2_0/> and all philosophical systems imply completeness. A <a3_0>logical<a3_0/> system is possible but an <b7_0>existential<b7_0/> system is not. "What is rational is actual; and what is actual is rational". Hegel's absolute idealism blurs the distinction between <b5_0>existence and thought<b5_0/>: our mortal nature places limits on our understanding of reality;
